question: Question_04_(i)
statement:
Consider the function

\[f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\] i) Determine
f(x) for $x \rightarrow \pm \infty.$
sols:
When considering limits at infinity, only that term with the highest
degree plays a role. So we can conclude instantly that the limit at
either positive or negative infinity will be positive infinity.

To illustrate why this is true, consider the full computation below. We
have that

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{4}x^4 -2x^3 + \frac{9}{2}x^2\\
&= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{4}x^4 (1-2 \frac{1}{x} + \frac{9}{2x^2})\\
&=  \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{4}x^4\\
&= +\infty
\end{align*}
hints:
Which term dominates the polynomial? What happens to it as it tends to
plus or minus infinity?
